comment.author: 65361386@N05
comment._content: Did a twist-reverse-contrast on this one, and all it says is the clear "British troops searching the Tolka for arms & ammunition". The same is written at the opposite end of the pic, but it's much more faint. Also says "Box A" and "H24" if that means anything? I'm curious though at the use of the term "British troops" ... . Given the probable date, wouldn't it have been just "troops"? Maybe I'm just looking for puzzles ... .

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/65361386@N05] The H24 is just the Irish Independent's reference. What I'm concerned about is the Box A. If the other one is from 1920 rather than 1916, does that imply that all the negatives from Box A were 1920? Or maybe storage wasn't that organised. Box A could have been something added way after the fact. Haven't forgotten this or the other one, and I'll be back to you asap...

And please keep looking for puzzles! We're all about the puzzles here...  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 65361386@N05
comment._content: Take your time! And by the way, I took a look at the Mount Street pic again, and its full reference is "Box A H23" (the H23 is upside down relative to the other writing). Bit coincidental that the two are consecutive? Curiouser and curiouser. I'm afraid I'm coming down in favour of both being 1920 ... 1920s may explaing the use of the words "British troops"? I wonder are there any in Box A that are indisputedly 1916?

comment.author: 98225546@N06
comment._content: there were many british troops in Dublin in 1916,particularly around easter that year! Also it is documented that their engineers were sent out to annesley bridge to carry out repairs on the thursday or wednesday of the rising and came under fire. The weather was unseasonable hot that easter as the lighting, tones, shadows and sky suggest.The water line is down a couple of inches suggesting fine weather and the tree in the background has not yet come into bloom but seems to be budding. It is very possibly from easter week 1916.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/98225546@N06] Thank you very much! Have to say that at this stage, I'd be very happy with the 1916 dating.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
